contentrichtext.text: '''Idistaviso''' is the location on the [[Weser river]] where forces commanded by [[Arminius]] fought those commanded by [[Germanicus]] at the [[Battle of the Weser River]] in 16 CE, attested in chapter 16 of [[Tacitus]]' ''[[Annals (Tacitus)|Annales]]'' II. The name was amended by [[Karl Müllenhoff]] and [[Jacob Grimm]] in the 19th century to '''Idisiaviso''', meaning "plain of the [[Idis (Germanic)|Idisi]]" or "women's meadow".<ref name=SIMEK171>Simek (2007:171).</ref> ==Theories== Rudolf Simek states that "as the Idisi are supposed to have an influence in the outcome of a battle, similarities with the [[valkyrie]]s suggest themselves. Idisiaviso would thus be a place at which the Idisi had once been instrumental in a battle."<ref name=SIMEK171/> Several etymologies of [[Iðavöllr]] (a location in [[Norse mythology]]) have been proposed, and the meaning of the name is considered unclear. If Iðavöllr is amended to ''*Ið[is]avöllr'', the location name corresponds precisely to ''Idisiaviso''.<ref name=SIMEK171/> ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * Simek, Rudolf (2007) translated by Angela Hall. ''Dictionary of Northern Mythology''. [[Boydell & Brewer|D. S. Brewer]].
